Content: you can't change the values so yes, use an index, like `for i in range(len(text)):` rather than `for word in text:`

Author: noob4ever#1127
Content: I have everything right except for the exit code. I return 1 when there are not two arguments, but when I execute ```echo $?``` after my program exits due to the wrong number of arguments I see a 0. What am I missing.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Use `sys.exit(1)`

Author: noob4ever#1127
Content: Thanks @Blauelf  that did the trick. What is the difference between ```return 1``` and ```sys.exit(1)``` My thinking was that by calling return it would exit the "main" function aka the program and the exit code would be "1". This does not appear to be the case though.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: `main` in Python is a function like any, its return value has no special meaning. `exit` is how you end with an exit code.

Author: noob4ever#1127
Content: So in C main was the program itself and using a ```return 1;``` was the exit code returned to the system aka the operating system. In python, because python is running the program and it is not compiled, return 1 just returns 1 to python and not the system. However, using sys.exit(1) tells python itself to return 1 to the OS it is running on. I think I may be **way** confused with this. If you happen to have a link to a resource that would explain this if I am wrong it might be easier. I've been googling around the past hour or so and still haven't found anything which explains this well.

Content: if you have a string `word = "word\n"`, then   `word.strip("\n")`  will return "word"

Content: or even simpler `word.strip()`  since that by default will strip a newline from the end

Author: Antony Mikhael#5177
Content: why doesn't it work when  including argv[1] but works when directly including the banned.txt ? what is wrong with my thought process ?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Use variable `openfile`, not string constant `'openfile'`.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
@mann I would not use `replace` at all. Maybe if you used regular expressions, but that's a big topic on its own. Here it should be sufficient to check whether the words are in your banned list, much like the list comprehension you have.
It's confusing how you use `words` for different things.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @Antony Mikhael Also, I would recommend checking out the `with` keyword, makes file handling nicer.

Author: Antony Mikhael#5177
Content: thanks but why don't we use the 'openfile' ? the documentation I found states the example with ' before and after the file name  ?

Author: Antony Mikhael#5177
Content: I am sorry for asking such a basic question but I could either rely on someone every time my code doesn't work or find a  way to understand the core problem which  is  understanding how to use the documentation better . ? so how do I know that I shouldn't include ' before and after the file name from the documentation ?

Author: Antony Mikhael#5177
Content: @Blauelf  honestly I had no idea that the keyword "with" existed until you have just suggested it now ,thanks alot .  but is it  normal that  we have to dig around to find these type of stuff by chance or am I missing something from the course ?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
The `'workfile'` of the example describes a file of that name, not a file name stored in a variable. Small differences in how string literals can be formatted, otherwise same as in C.
And while I prefer using `with`, you'll find enough examples closing the file manually. Python's documentation is a bit... interesting. They have some official tutorial which isn't that bad.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: And yeah, at this point in the course, digging is expected. Just be careful when digging up an answer on StackOverflow from 2009, it might no longer apply.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Typing the right search queries is a skill to train, too.

Author: Antony Mikhael#5177
Content: oh okay thanks alot , that is really helpful . I really appreciate your help

Content: This is the same file (bleep.py) submitted 3 times in a row with different scores each time.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: when that happens, it generally means that your program is doing something strange with memory.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: or something to do with how you are asking for user input.

Author: Grimrath#0353
Content: Can I send you the code to see if I'm doing something wrong? Because I have no idea at all

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I can see it in the submissions. I don't see anything wrong either. I think perhaps check50 was just running slowly, but I'll ask the team.

Author: Grimrath#0353
Content: Very grateful, thanks @curiouskiwi

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: in the meantime, looks like your latest got 8/8 so you're all set with it

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Grimrath so it does look like some sort of timing issue which only happens occasionally (I ran check50 on your code 5x and it got 8/8 each time).  But we think it might be because of the newline char at the beginning of your prompt:  ```inmessage = get_string("\nWhat message would you like to censor?\n")```  that might confuse check50's test for a prompt. (it sees the empty line first and reports a missing prompt)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: as I said, no action required on your part now since you have the 8/8 score as your latest.

Author: Grimrath#0353
Content: I'll clean it up in the local file. Will keep that in mind going forward! Thanks üôÇ

consider this: ```python

# results in:

# found 8```
